attributes.title: The Demand for Democracy: An Experimental Analysis

q1.value: The Demand for Democracy: An Experimental Analysis

q2.value: John A Doces | Mark J. Meyer

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We find in Côte d'Ivoire and Uganda that the demand for democracy is not as strong as commonly thought. In this paper, we conduct exact replications of our earlier results in Côte d'Ivoire and extend the analysis to Senegal. Here, we have six hypotheses that we will test, as described more fully below.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1. Democracy will have its highest level of support when compared to the most general groupings. Hypothesis 2. Compared to roads, water and electricity, democracy will have relatively less support than categories that are more excludable. Hypothesis 3. Compared to education and health, democracy will have relatively less support than categories that are more excludable. Hypothesis 4. Compared to industry and mining, democracy will have higher levels of support than categories more public in nature. Hypothesis 5. Compared to trade and tourism, democracy will have higher levels of support than categories more public in nature. Hypothesis 6. Compared to agriculture and forestry and fishing, democracy will have lower levels of support than industry and mining.

q17.value: Survey experiment using a conjoint analysis.

attributes.title: Rawls for Realists An Empirical Investigation of the Relationship of National Identity and Social Justice

q1.value: Rawls for Realists An Empirical Investigation of the Relationship of National Identity and Social Justice

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Strong national attachments are often thought to increase anti-immigrant sentiments and reduce the inclusiveness of a political community for immigrants in developed and stable democracies. At the same time national attachment is often believed to foster solidarity within political communities. In my thesis I empirically investigate these two arguments and put forward the hypothesis that these relationships are dependent on individual-level characteristics that go beyond classical socioeconomic factors: core personality and one’s conception of national identity (nativism). The internet survey experiment (N=900) is designed to test the empirical regularities found in the observational data of my first two papers.

q17.value: Generally, I will pool the two treatment conditions (long and short video) and compare with them with the control group (no video). In a second step, to test hypothesis H1c, I will compare all three conditions against each other. For estimation, I will use ordinary least square regressions of the indicator outcomes. In a first step, I will estimate simple bivariate regressions of the outcomes on the treatment condition without control variables. I will graph coefficients from these regressions in simple coefplots with 95% confidence intervals. Second, to increase precision, I will control for the baseline covariates, listed below, in a second specification. For the hypotheses about heterogeneous treatment effects, I will assign respondents to groups based on their baseline covariates in the following way: • Respondents that score above 2 on the 4-point scale on the nativism scale are considered “nativists”, the others “non-nativists” • Respondents without an advanced degree are considered low education, the rest high education. • I will distinguish between male and female respondents based on the baseline responses. • If respondents respond that they would vote Labour/Tory in the next parliamentary election, they are treated as Labour/Tory voters.

q27.value: The survey is disseminated by amicrotasking platform.

attributes.title: Traditional Leadership, Social Networks, and Collective Action in Northern Ghana

q1.value: Traditional Leadership, Social Networks, and Collective Action in Northern Ghana

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This pre-analysis plan documents planned data collection and analyses for the first stage of a study exploring how community-level social networks shape collective action and political behavior in rural communities of Northern Ghana. We employ a field experiment embedded within a "lab-in-the-field" public goods activity to explore the relationship between participants' social network positions and their cooperative behavior.

q16.value: We examine several sets of hypotheses. First, we explore observationally how the location of participants within their community social network structure -- their centrality, their proximity to each other, and, importantly, their proximity to community leaders such as the traditional chief -- predicts cooperative behavior in a public goods activity. Second, we examine two experimental interventions. The main intervention varies the timing of when participants' donations are collected, and with it, the opportunity to interact with and coordinate with each other in donation behavior, choice of leaders, and preferences for projects. We use this randomly assigned treatment as a means to assess how coordination among community members varies differentially across their locations in the social network, focusing in particular on how the proximity of individuals to community leaders -- who have an opportunity during the delay in the collection of donations to steer contributions in a favored direction -- may result in different behavior.

q17.value: The hypotheses are tested with data gathered from a survey of approximately 550 households in 6 rural communities. The survey will map the full household-level network structure of these communities across several social and political domains and then conclude with the public goods activity. The planned analyses using this survey data vary across multiple estimation approaches as appropriate for each specific hypothesis. The analyses are described in detail in the attached pre-analysis plan.

q24.value: HUM00147575 (University of Michigan Health and Behavioral Sciences Institutional Review Board)

attributes.title: Conditional Ethnic Loyalty: Latino Support for Coethnic Candidates

q1.value: Conditional Ethnic Loyalty: Latino Support for Coethnic Candidates

q5.value: Thank you to the Princeton Politics Department, specifically Michele Epstein, Paul Frymer, Andy Guess, Patricia Kirkland, Tali Mendelberg, Jonathan Mummolo, Marc Ratkovic, LaFleur Stephens-Dougan, and Omar Wasow for your help and feedback on initial iterations of this project. A special thank you to my adviser Ali Valenzuela, who has provided so much helpful advice to propel this project., Finally, thank you to my family for all of the love, support, and direct feedback you have provided as this project has gone from beginning to now.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In this proposal, I present an experimental test of the “coethnic effect” that also accounts for the simultaneous effects of partisanship, issue positions on immigration and abortion, and organizational endorsements by Latino and non-Latino organizations. To examine these questions, I will conduct a survey experiment on Qualtrics simulating elections for governor with an online population of Latino voting-age respondents accessed through the online research firm Cint. In this experiment, I will present respondents with a series of four unique candidate-choice tasks. In each task, they will view two randomly generated candidates for a hypothetical gubernatorial election, evaluate both candidates, and record their vote choice. The candidates will vary based on their partisanship (Democrat or Republican), ethnoracial identity (Latino or white), issue positions (pro- or anti-immigration and abortion), age (a range from 35-60), gender (male or female), and organizational endorsements (Latino and non-Latino business or labor organizations). The traits of each candidate will be randomized following a conjoint design, which allows me to test individual dimensions along with their combinations (Hainmueller, Hopkins, and Yamamoto, 2014). By presenting respondents with Latino and non-Latino (white) candidates who vary on these dimensions, I can assess what is driving Latino support for coethnics and whether this effect holds for a variety of other candidate types. Additionally, by recording a variety of individual level characteristics such as Latino identity strength, national origin, partisan identity, and policy views, I can evaluate whether different groups of Latino respondents have distinct reactions to particular candidate types.

q16.value: My two outcomes of interest will be a binary choice for each candidate (0 not chosen, 1 chosen) and a scale for how negative or positive (7pt) the respondents feel towards each individual candidate profile. The hypotheses to be tested are as follows: H1 – Coethnic vs. Democratic Loyalty: Latino candidates will only receive more support when it does not conflict with support for a Democratic candidate. H1a – Coethnic Advantage in Primaries: Latino candidates will receive significantly more support in primary elections (Democrat vs. Democrat or Republican vs. Republican) due to the absence of a partisan choice. This effect will be especially apparent among respondents who have high levels of Latino identity strength measurements. H1b – Democratic Advantage in Generals: Latino candidates will not receive significantly more support in general elections; instead, Democratic candidates will receive significantly more support regardless of their race/ethnicity. This effect will be especially apparent among respondents who are strongly identified with being a Democrat. H2 – Republicans Against Type (Pro-Immigration): While Republican candidates will receive less support overall, those who are pro-immigration will receive significantly more support than all other Republican candidates. H3 – Latino Coethnicity as a Cue: Latino candidates will be associated with liberal immigration policy and Latino organizations, and this association (rather than a pure coethnic support effect) will determine support for candidates who are Latino, pro-immigrant, and/or endorsed by Latino organizations. These effects will be especially apparent among respondents who have high Latino identity strength and/or liberal immigration policy preferences. H3a – Latinos Against Type (Anti-Immigration): Latino candidates who are anti-immigration will receive significantly less support than other Latino candidates. H3b – Latino Coethnicity as Immigration Policy Cue: Latino candidates who are pro-immigration will not receive significantly more support than those who do not adopt an immigration position (pro/anti-abortion), controlling for respondent views on abortion. H3c – Latino Coethnicity as Latino Endorsement Cue: Latino candidates who are endorsed by a Latino organization will not receive significantly more support than those who are endorsed by a non-Latino organization. H3d– Latino Identity Cue Transference: Candidates who are NOT coethnic (i.e. White) but who have pro-Latino positions (pro-immigration or endorsed by a Latino organization) will receive similar levels of support compared to Latino candidates.

q17.value: For my outcomes of interest, I will firstly use the binary vote choice measure (where respondents are forced to choose) and will then use candidate evaluations (a 7pt. scale where each candidate is evaluated independently). To evaluate these hypotheses, I will use two different approaches: a measure of differences between treatment and reference groups, and a linear regression model using treatment assignments as variables of interest. For the measure of difference, I will compare groups as outlined in my hypotheses and assess whether the differences between these populations reaches statistical significance or not. For example, to test H1a – Coethnic Advantage in Primaries, I will analyze candidates in primary elections and compare those who are Latino with those who are White. Then, using a T-test, I will determine whether there is a significant difference between these two populations of candidates.

attributes.title: Tax Incidence in the Market for Medical Devices

q1.value: Tax Incidence in the Market for Medical Devices

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This project estimates the tax incidence of a narrowly defined medical device excise tax in the US. The goal is to estimate the deadweight loss of the tax, who bears the economic costs, and how the fundamentals of the market for healthcare in the US affect the allocation of the costs. There are large literatures on gasoline, alcohol, and tobacco excise taxes, but there is a gap in the literature in understanding excise taxes in the market for healthcare or for similarly narrow excise taxes. This project uses novel variation in the definition of a taxable medical device and some loopholes that make nearly identical devices have different tax treatments to identify the tax passthrough, or portion of the tax that the agent who owes the tax adds to the price. This paper implements methods surveyed by Fabinger and Weyl (2013) to use estimates of pass-through to characterize the allocation of the total cost of the tax across the relevant parties. The medical device excise tax was cited as one of the two reasons for the US government shutdown in 2013 and has garnered a large amount of political ill-will despite very little being known about its economic impact, and this paper seeks to fill this gap in the literature.

q16.value: Several different parties claim to bear the economic cost of the medical device tax that was in place from 2013-2015 in the US. Device manufacturers claim that they are unable to pass along any of the tax while hospitals and insurers claim the tax raises the price of care. This project seeks to quantify who actually bears the economic incidence of the tax and the associated dead weight loss. In order to characterize the economic impact of the medical device tax passed in tandem with the ACA, this project will estimate several basic economic parameters. First, the project estimates the pass-through of taxes from device manufacturers to device buyers. Next, the demand for medical devices will be estimated using data on prices and quantities from hospitals around the US before the implementation of the tax. Finally, this project will use methods from the Industrial Organization literature to estimate markups on medical devices. These economic primitives will be used to describe the economic incidence of the medical device tax.

q17.value: The economic incidence of the medical device tax will be quantified using a differences in differences approach to measuring price changes around the implementation of the tax. Some device classes are exempt from the tax while nearly identical devices are taxable. For instance, medical grade tubing used for enteral feeding is exempt while most medical tubing used for non-enteral purposes is taxable. A differences in differences approach is used to quantify the price change after the implementation of the tax.

attributes.title: Reducing conspiracy theories about disease epidemics: experimental evidence from Brazil

q1.value: Reducing conspiracy theories about disease epidemics: experimental evidence from Brazil

q2.value: John Michael Carey | Victoria Chi | D.J. Flynn | Brendan Nyhan | Thomas Zeitzoff

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: (This preregistration describes a planned follow-up study to EGAP 20170412AB: “Effects of Public Health Messages about Zika.” What follows was adapted from the prior preregistration.) Public health depends on the widespread availability of accurate scientific information. The proliferation of conspiracy theories and other misinformation about health, medicine, and science have therefore created a significant challenge for public health officials. These theories often fill the void created by a lack of public understanding of a scientific or health issue and often persist and even gain credibility despite clear evidence to the contrary as they circulate in public discourse and through social networks. For instance, many people in Brazil --- the center of the recent Zika and yellow fever (YF) epidemics --- seemingly do not understand the causes of these viruses, the reasons for their spread, or the consequences they can have for people’s health. Rumors and unsupported reports have blamed the mosquito-borne diseases and public health consequences on genetically modified mosquitoes, larvicides, and prenatal vaccines. The spread of these conspiracy theories could threaten public health efforts to prevent Zika and YF by dissuading people from protecting themselves, undermining efforts to enlist the public’s help in preventing the spread of these diseases, and reducing support for responses to the outbreaks by public health officials. Public health officials have employed a variety of messaging strategies to inform the public and counter these false beliefs. However, the effectiveness of realistic health messaging interventions addressing misperceptions have only been evaluated in a limited number of cases. How should public health officials respond? In previous research, we examined the influence of corrective information, which we adapted from the Pan-American Health Organization, about the Zika virus on factual beliefs, opinions, and intended behavior (we also tested two other types of messages not discussed here). Results indicated that the corrective message failed to reduce conspiracy beliefs about the causes of Zika relative to a control condition; moreover, the correction actually reduced factual knowledge about the true causes and consequences of Zika relative to control. One possible explanation for these results is that corrective information reduced respondents’ confidence in their understanding of disease epidemics or scientific issues more generally, which caused them to express lower levels of agreement with nearly all claims. The present study has two objectives. First, we examine the generalizability of our previous results by replicating the Zika experiment on a second sample and by conducting a similar experiment on another epidemic currently plaguing Brazil: YF. Second, to test the theoretical explanation discussed above, we include a series of “placebo” belief outcomes in the new Zika and YF experiments in order to examine whether our corrective treatment reduces agreement with facts that are unrelated to the information provided in the treatments. (Both the Zika and YF experiments will have the same design, which we discuss below. The design compares a myths-and-facts style correction to a placebo condition that represents the no information baseline.)

q16.value: We will test the hypotheses below, which were pre-registered before our previous Zika study, for both Zika and YF. For consistency, we maintain the same hypothesis numbers as the previous study. (From the prior study, we exclude hypothesis H1b about over-time effects since the present study includes only one wave; hypothesis H4a/H4b, which predicted heterogeneous treatment effects that were not observed in the previous study; and research questions RQ1-3, which pertain to over-time effects and treatments that were not tested in this study and heterogeneous treatment effects that were not observed in the previous study.) Specifically, we will again test our original hypothesis that a message correcting myths and providing facts (which we refer to below as a “myths and facts message”) will reduce beliefs in myths about the Zika/YF virus and correspondingly increase accuracy of respondents’ beliefs about the true causes of Zika/YF and their effects on health relative to a placebo condition (H1a). This expectation is consistent with Nyhan and Reifler (2015), who argue that causal explanations for events are more effective than denials alone. In this case, the myths and facts condition both debunks myths about a communicable disease and instead explains how the disease is spread (i.e., by the Aedes aegypti mosquito) and its effects (e.g., that Zika is responsible for the increase in neurological problems observed among infants). If this myths and facts message is effective at reducing belief in myths about GMO mosquitoes, larvicides, and TDAP (Zika arm) and the YF vaccine and propolis alternative (YF arm), it should also have corresponding effects on support for these policies (H2) and increase respondents’ intention to protect themselves from the Aedes aegypti mosquito (H3). We also test the following hypotheses, which extend our findings from the earlier study: H5a: A myths and facts message will decrease respondents’ belief in factual claims about Zika/YF, including those that are unrelated to the content of the treatment message (we specify which outcome measures we define as unrelated below). H5b: A myths and facts message will decrease respondents’ confidence in their ability to find the truth behind medical and health disputes.

q17.value: We will randomize participants into either the Zika or YF arms of the study and then into one of two experimental conditions in a between-subjects design. In both arms, the treatment (myths and facts) condition will be compared to the placebo (control) condition. We will test the effectiveness of a myths and facts message about Zika/YF versus the placebo condition on beliefs about Zika/YF (both knowledge of how the diseases are actually transmitted and belief in myths about the diseases), support for policies to prevent their spread, and intention to engage in preventive and protective behaviors. (See the statistical analysis section below for details.) Respondents and data collection The procedure to be used: We will field a survey containing both the Zika and YF experiments to a targeted sample size of 2,000 by the online survey vendor SSI. Prior to beginning the study, participants will be provided with a description of the survey and reminded that participation in the study is voluntary and that they are free to withdraw at any time. Participants will then be asked to indicate whether or not they agree to participate in the survey. Each participant will be randomly assigned to the Zika placebo condition, the Zika myths and facts condition, and YF placebo condition, or the YF myths and facts condition. Respondents will receive a full debriefing at the conclusion of the study. SSI will not provide any identifiable information to the investigators about the study participants, nor will we ask about any identifying information. The nature of data to be obtained: We will collect individual-level survey data, including questions about demographic/political characteristics, political and health knowledge, beliefs and self-reported intended behavior. Respondents will also be asked in what state or district they live. Dates of administration The study will be made available to respondents on May 16, 2018 and kept in the field until the target sample size has been reached. Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants All residents of Brazil age 18 or older are eligible to participate in the study. Participants must be members of the SSI panel to be selected for inclusion. Respondents from the prior study will be excluded. Primary and secondary outcome measures The wording of all of the outcome measures are provided below. We will construct scales for the following outcome measures listed below: [Zika study] -Zika knowledge: Infected by bite, neurological effects, infected by sex, not infected by casual contact, weak immune systems, infected during pregnancy, pregnant women, donated blood, paralysis -Zika conspiracy theories: GMO mosquitoes, larvicides causing microcephaly, vaccines causing microcephaly -Policy opinions: Release genetically modified mosquitoes, government recommendation of Tdap vaccine, use larvicides in water, government inspections -Behavioral intentions: Intend to wear long-sleeved shirts and pants, use mosquito spray/repellent, use screens or close windows to keep mosquitoes out If three or more of the questions used for each scale load on the same factor using principal components factor analysis, we will consider the composite measure as the outcome measure of interest. If they do not, we will examine them separately, though we may also estimate the total effects on average belief accuracy. To test H1a, H2, and H3, we will estimate models of the following form (in pseudo Stata code) separately for the Zika and YF studies. The models will include all belief outcomes above (H1a), all policy preference outcomes (H2), and all behavioral intent outcomes (H3). reg Y mythsandfacts, robust To test H5a, we distinguish between belief outcomes that are related and unrelated to the information provided in our experimental treatments, respectively. We use the subset of unrelated items to test H5a. In both studies, these items are: [Zika study:] -Unrelated: neurological effects, infected by sex, not infected by casual contact, weak immune systems, infected during pregnancy, pregnant women, donated blood, paralysis [YF study:] -Unrelated: same type of mosquito, symptoms, can be fatal, government recommendation, increasingly common in cities, children's immune systems, Pharma hoax We will estimate a model of the same form above. To test H5b, we will use an adapted version of the epistemic political efficacy scale (Pingree 2011), which focuses on knowledge about health and medicine. If all three questions in this scale load on the same factor using principal components factor analysis, we will consider the composite measure as the outcome measure of interest. If they do not, we will examine them separately. Notes: -Per Franco et al. (N.d.), all estimates of experimental effects will be unweighted even if SSI provides survey weights for respondents. -For interaction terms, scales, and moderators, if results are consistent using a median/tercile split or indicators rather than a continuous scale, we may present the latter in the main text for ease of exposition and include the continuous scale results in an appendix. We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from the models described below. We will also use tercile indicators to test whether the linearity assumption holds for interactions per Hainmueller et al (N.d.) and replace the continuous interactions in our models with them if it does not. -We will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models, including treatment effects by subgroup and differences in marginal effects between subgroups. -We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from any interaction models. In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible. -Don’t know responses will be considered missing data for the factual belief outcome measures. -We will also compute and report summary statistics for our samples. We will also collect and may report response timing data as a proxy for respondent attention. -The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. -Where applicable, regression results for binary dependent variables will be verified for robustness using probit. Regression results for individual ordered dependent variables will be verified for robustness using ordered probit. -We may estimate the models described above with a standard set of covariates (age group indicators, gender indicator, racial group indicators, education, scores on a pre-treatment science knowledge scale, and state/territory fixed effects) if including those has a substantively important effect on the precision of our treatment effect estimates. In that case, however, both models will be reported.

registration_responses.q1: Reducing conspiracy theories about disease epidemics: experimental evidence from Brazil
registration_responses.q2: John Michael Carey | Victoria Chi | D.J. Flynn | Brendan Nyhan | Thomas Zeitzoff
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: (This preregistration describes a planned follow-up study to EGAP 20170412AB: “Effects of Public Health Messages about Zika.” What follows was adapted from the prior preregistration.) Public health depends on the widespread availability of accurate scientific information. The proliferation of conspiracy theories and other misinformation about health, medicine, and science have therefore created a significant challenge for public health officials. These theories often fill the void created by a lack of public understanding of a scientific or health issue and often persist and even gain credibility despite clear evidence to the contrary as they circulate in public discourse and through social networks. For instance, many people in Brazil --- the center of the recent Zika and yellow fever (YF) epidemics --- seemingly do not understand the causes of these viruses, the reasons for their spread, or the consequences they can have for people’s health. Rumors and unsupported reports have blamed the mosquito-borne diseases and public health consequences on genetically modified mosquitoes, larvicides, and prenatal vaccines. The spread of these conspiracy theories could threaten public health efforts to prevent Zika and YF by dissuading people from protecting themselves, undermining efforts to enlist the public’s help in preventing the spread of these diseases, and reducing support for responses to the outbreaks by public health officials. Public health officials have employed a variety of messaging strategies to inform the public and counter these false beliefs. However, the effectiveness of realistic health messaging interventions addressing misperceptions have only been evaluated in a limited number of cases. How should public health officials respond? In previous research, we examined the influence of corrective information, which we adapted from the Pan-American Health Organization, about the Zika virus on factual beliefs, opinions, and intended behavior (we also tested two other types of messages not discussed here). Results indicated that the corrective message failed to reduce conspiracy beliefs about the causes of Zika relative to a control condition; moreover, the correction actually reduced factual knowledge about the true causes and consequences of Zika relative to control. One possible explanation for these results is that corrective information reduced respondents’ confidence in their understanding of disease epidemics or scientific issues more generally, which caused them to express lower levels of agreement with nearly all claims. The present study has two objectives. First, we examine the generalizability of our previous results by replicating the Zika experiment on a second sample and by conducting a similar experiment on another epidemic currently plaguing Brazil: YF. Second, to test the theoretical explanation discussed above, we include a series of “placebo” belief outcomes in the new Zika and YF experiments in order to examine whether our corrective treatment reduces agreement with facts that are unrelated to the information provided in the treatments. (Both the Zika and YF experiments will have the same design, which we discuss below. The design compares a myths-and-facts style correction to a placebo condition that represents the no information baseline.)
registration_responses.q16: We will test the hypotheses below, which were pre-registered before our previous Zika study, for both Zika and YF. For consistency, we maintain the same hypothesis numbers as the previous study. (From the prior study, we exclude hypothesis H1b about over-time effects since the present study includes only one wave; hypothesis H4a/H4b, which predicted heterogeneous treatment effects that were not observed in the previous study; and research questions RQ1-3, which pertain to over-time effects and treatments that were not tested in this study and heterogeneous treatment effects that were not observed in the previous study.) Specifically, we will again test our original hypothesis that a message correcting myths and providing facts (which we refer to below as a “myths and facts message”) will reduce beliefs in myths about the Zika/YF virus and correspondingly increase accuracy of respondents’ beliefs about the true causes of Zika/YF and their effects on health relative to a placebo condition (H1a). This expectation is consistent with Nyhan and Reifler (2015), who argue that causal explanations for events are more effective than denials alone. In this case, the myths and facts condition both debunks myths about a communicable disease and instead explains how the disease is spread (i.e., by the Aedes aegypti mosquito) and its effects (e.g., that Zika is responsible for the increase in neurological problems observed among infants). If this myths and facts message is effective at reducing belief in myths about GMO mosquitoes, larvicides, and TDAP (Zika arm) and the YF vaccine and propolis alternative (YF arm), it should also have corresponding effects on support for these policies (H2) and increase respondents’ intention to protect themselves from the Aedes aegypti mosquito (H3). We also test the following hypotheses, which extend our findings from the earlier study: H5a: A myths and facts message will decrease respondents’ belief in factual claims about Zika/YF, including those that are unrelated to the content of the treatment message (we specify which outcome measures we define as unrelated below). H5b: A myths and facts message will decrease respondents’ confidence in their ability to find the truth behind medical and health disputes.
registration_responses.q17: We will randomize participants into either the Zika or YF arms of the study and then into one of two experimental conditions in a between-subjects design. In both arms, the treatment (myths and facts) condition will be compared to the placebo (control) condition. We will test the effectiveness of a myths and facts message about Zika/YF versus the placebo condition on beliefs about Zika/YF (both knowledge of how the diseases are actually transmitted and belief in myths about the diseases), support for policies to prevent their spread, and intention to engage in preventive and protective behaviors. (See the statistical analysis section below for details.) Respondents and data collection The procedure to be used: We will field a survey containing both the Zika and YF experiments to a targeted sample size of 2,000 by the online survey vendor SSI. Prior to beginning the study, participants will be provided with a description of the survey and reminded that participation in the study is voluntary and that they are free to withdraw at any time. Participants will then be asked to indicate whether or not they agree to participate in the survey. Each participant will be randomly assigned to the Zika placebo condition, the Zika myths and facts condition, and YF placebo condition, or the YF myths and facts condition. Respondents will receive a full debriefing at the conclusion of the study. SSI will not provide any identifiable information to the investigators about the study participants, nor will we ask about any identifying information. The nature of data to be obtained: We will collect individual-level survey data, including questions about demographic/political characteristics, political and health knowledge, beliefs and self-reported intended behavior. Respondents will also be asked in what state or district they live. Dates of administration The study will be made available to respondents on May 16, 2018 and kept in the field until the target sample size has been reached. Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants All residents of Brazil age 18 or older are eligible to participate in the study. Participants must be members of the SSI panel to be selected for inclusion. Respondents from the prior study will be excluded. Primary and secondary outcome measures The wording of all of the outcome measures are provided below. If they do not, we will examine them separately, though we may also estimate the total effects on average belief accuracy. (Note: Though we will analyze the component questions of our primary outcome measure using principal component factor analysis, we will construct any combined outcome measure as a mean for ease of interpretation.) We may also conduct exploratory analyses of individual outcome questions even when the scale is the primary outcome of interest. There are objective facts behind most disputes over health and science, and if you try hard enough you can find them. -Strongly agree [4] -Somewhat agree [3] -Somewhat disagree [2] -Strongly disagree [1] Statistical analyses All results will be estimated using OLS with robust standard errors and verified for robustness using appropriate GLM estimators (see below). All factual belief measures are coded such that higher values = greater perceptions of accuracy (though we may reverse-code these for expositional purposes in some cases). To test H1a, H2, and H3, we will estimate models of the following form (in pseudo Stata code) separately for the Zika and YF studies. The models will include all belief outcomes above (H1a), all policy preference outcomes (H2), and all behavioral intent outcomes (H3). reg Y mythsandfacts, robust To test H5a, we distinguish between belief outcomes that are related and unrelated to the information provided in our experimental treatments, respectively. We use the subset of unrelated items to test H5a. In both studies, these items are: [Zika study:] -Unrelated: neurological effects, infected by sex, not infected by casual contact, weak immune systems, infected during pregnancy, pregnant women, donated blood, paralysis [YF study:] -Unrelated: same type of mosquito, symptoms, can be fatal, government recommendation, increasingly common in cities, children's immune systems, Pharma hoax We will estimate a model of the same form above. To test H5b, we will use an adapted version of the epistemic political efficacy scale (Pingree 2011), which focuses on knowledge about health and medicine. If all three questions in this scale load on the same factor using principal components factor analysis, we will consider the composite measure as the outcome measure of interest. If they do not, we will examine them separately. (Note: Though we will analyze the component questions of our primary outcome measure using principal component factor analysis, we will construct any combined outcome measure as a mean for ease of interpretation.) We may also conduct exploratory analyses of individual outcome questions even when the scale is the primary outcome of interest. We will estimate a model of the same form above. Notes: -Per Franco et al. (N.d.), all estimates of experimental effects will be unweighted even if SSI provides survey weights for respondents. -For interaction terms, scales, and moderators, if results are consistent using a median/tercile split or indicators rather than a continuous scale, we may present the latter in the main text for ease of exposition and include the continuous scale results in an appendix. We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from the models described below. We will also use tercile indicators to test whether the linearity assumption holds for interactions per Hainmueller et al (N.d.) and replace the continuous interactions in our models with them if it does not. -We will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models, including treatment effects by subgroup and differences in marginal effects between subgroups. -We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from any interaction models. In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible. -Don’t know responses will be considered missing data for the factual belief outcome measures. -We will also compute and report summary statistics for our samples. We will also collect and may report response timing data as a proxy for respondent attention. -The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. -Where applicable, regression results for binary dependent variables will be verified for robustness using probit. Regression results for individual ordered dependent variables will be verified for robustness using ordered probit. -We may estimate the models described above with a standard set of covariates (age group indicators, gender indicator, racial group indicators, education, scores on a pre-treatment science knowledge scale, and state/territory fixed effects) if including those has a substantively important effect on the precision of our treatment effect estimates. In that case, however, both models will be reported.

attributes.title: Postal Voter Recruitment and Turnout Experiment

q1.value: Postal Voter Recruitment and Turnout Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: We use a randomised control trial (RCT) to test the effect of partisan letters on the uptake of postal voting in the United Kingdom. Households in Southwark, London were randomly assigned to receive a letter from the local Liberal Democrats encouraging them to apply for postal voting either online or by returning to the local council an enclosed postal voter application form. Our aim is to test (1) whether a party’s efforts to recruit known supporters to postal votes is effective, and (2) whether these efforts have an effect on the turnout of these supporters. Evidence from the US suggests that it is possible to change voters’ registration from the traditional, in-person status, to postal voter status (or ‘Vote-By-Mail’) . However, existing studies have been conducted in the US, with limited research conducted in the UK. The first (and to our knowledge, only) experiment to test partisan efforts to mobilise voters through vote-by-mail was also conducted in the US, during the 2016 elections. Hassell’s (2017) experiment tested the effect of encouragements to vote-by-mail sent on behalf of the Republican Party to Republican supporters in Minnesota. The results suggest that party supporters sent a letter urging them to vote-by-mail were indeed more likely to do so. Our study broadly replicates Hassell’s study. We hope to build on existing research by adding another partisan experiment that tests the effect of treatments urging voters to vote-by-mail – this time, in Britain. Given the imbalance of existing experiments towards non-partisan, US-based studies, we hope to examine whether these findings generalise to postal voting recruitment in a UK context. The experiment represents (to our knowledge) the first partisan postal vote recruitment study to be conducted outside the US.

q16.value: The first hypothesis is that individuals living in households that receive encouragements to register for a postal vote will see higher postal vote registration. The second hypothesis is that those in the treatment group will also see a higher turnout rate at the local election.

q17.value: We will measure the intent-to-treat (ITT) of treatments on both of our outcome measures (postal voter registration and turnout). As the experiment is cluster randomised at household level, our regression models will include clusters for households. We will regress postal voter registration on assignment, using covariates to generate more precise estimates.

attributes.title: Trading Favors: A Conjoint Experiment About Community Organizing and Local Politics

q1.value: Trading Favors: A Conjoint Experiment About Community Organizing and Local Politics

q5.value: I am grateful to the EGAP Metaketa III: Natural Resources initiative for generous research support and Aline Martins for excellent research assistance.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Public service access can also vary dramatically between neighborhoods in the same city or municipality, but the existing literature struggles to explain why. During extensive interviews in Northeast Brazil, I was struck by the variation between rural communities that were five kilometers apart. How do citizens influence the distribution of public services? I provide an alternative explanation for variation in public service provision. In an original theory of “trading favors,” I argue that groups of voters organize and trade their collective votes for preferential access to public services. In particular, local community associations provide a platform for voters to increase their bargaining power towards politicians, and I focus on characteristics of community involvement with the association, leadership characteristics, and political relationships between community leaders and local politicians. As a test of my theory, I seek to understand how rural residents perceive the impact of different community features on the multiple outcomes of public service access, connections with influential political representatives for access to services, bloc voting, and individual clientelism. I conduct a conjoint experiment that is embedded in the endline survey of the EGAP Metaketa III: Natural Resources initiative. See pre-analysis plan for additional motivation.

q16.value: The goal of the conjoint experiment is to comparatively evaluate the drivers of four outcomes: public service access, political broker, bloc voting, and clientelism. Specifically, I test five possible drivers and interactions between them, with the following hypotheses. The hypotheses are in the same direction for public service access, political representative, and bloc voting. They differ for some drivers for the outcome of individual clientelism. Public Service Access 1. Communities with strong participation in the association are more likely to have better public service access. 2. Communities with responsive association leadership are more likely to have better public service access. 3. Communities where the association leader endorses a political candidate are more likely to have better public service access. 4. Communities with high competition for leadership are more likely to have better public service access. 5. Communities with constant leadership are more likely to have better public service access. 6. Communities with strong participation in the association and where the association leader endorses a political candidate (INTERACTION EFFECT) are more likely to have better public service access. 7. Communities with high competition and constant leadership (INTERACTION EFFECT) are more likely to have better public service access. Political Representative 8. Communities with strong participation in the association are more likely to have a political representative to get resources for them. 9. Communities with responsive association leadership are more likely to have a political representative to get resources for them. 10. Communities where the association leader endorses a political candidate are more likely to have a political representative to get resources for them. 11. Communities with high competition for leadership are more likely to have a political representative to get resources for them. 12. Communities with constant leadership are more likely to have a political representative to get resources for them. 13. Communities with strong participation in the association and where the association leader endorses a political candidate (INTERACTION EFFECT) are more likely to have a political representative to get resources for them. 14. Communities with high competition and constant leadership (INTERACTION EFFECT) are more likely to have a political representative to get resources for them. Bloc Voting 15. Communities with strong participation in the association are more likely to organize to vote for one candidate. 16. Communities with responsive association leadership are more likely to organize to vote for one candidate. 17. Communities where the association leader endorses a political candidate are more likely to organize to vote for one candidate. 18. Communities with high competition are more likely to organize to vote for one candidate. 19. Communities with constant leadership are more likely to organize to vote for one candidate. 20. Communities with strong participation in the association and where the association leader endorses a political candidate (INTERACTION EFFECT) are more likely to organize to vote for one candidate. 21. Communities with high competition and constant leadership (INTERACTION EFFECT) are more likely to organize to vote for one candidate. Clientelism 22. Communities with weak participation in the association are more likely to have individual vote-buying. 23. Communities with non-responsive association leadership are more likely to have individual vote-buying. 24. Communities where the association leader does not endorse a political candidate are more likely to have individual vote-buying. 25. Communities with high competition and leadership turnover (INTERACTION EFFECT) are more likely to have individual vote-buying.

q17.value: To test my hypotheses about the relative effectiveness of the dimensions of community associations, I conduct a conjoint survey experiment embedded in the endline survey of EGAP Metaketa III with rural residents in the semi-arid region of Northeast Brazil. The pre-analysis plan for the project associated with this metaketa can be found here: http://egap.org/registration/4480. Conjoint experiments have a complex design that is difficult to implement in rural field settings with low education or illiterate populations. To overcome these challenges, I created pictogram booklets with five varying features of a community association. All combinations are plausible and were included in the experiment, which led to 32 unique profiles. The features are the following: 1. Community participation (strong/weak) 2. Leadership responsiveness (high/low) 3. Political endorsement (yes/no) 4. Leadership competition (high/low) 5. Leadership turnover (low/high) See pre-analysis plan for additional detail on profiles and outcome questions.

attributes.title: Nationalist Repression in China and Japan

q1.value: Nationalist Repression in China and Japan

q2.value: Trevor Incerti | Daniel Mattingly | Frances Rosenbluth | Seiki Tanaka | Jiahua Yue

q5.value: We would like to thank the Japan Foundation Center for Global Partnership and the Council on East Asian Studies at Yale University for generous financial support, Kazuma Hayamaru, and Mike Medeiros.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Nationalist sentiment is hypothesized to constrain both authoritarian and democratic regimes. Democracies are unable to repress nationalist actions as the ruling party will be punished at the polls. In autocracies, repressed actors or repressive agents can morph into political rivals. We investigate whether two governments – one authoritarian (China) and one democratic (Japan) – can effectively repress popular nationalism, and attempt to isolate the regime- related constraints they face. We use a survey experiment deployed in both countries to examine differences in levels of public support for government repression in both nationalist and non-nationalist, neutral contexts. By leveraging a politically sensitive territorial dispute common to both countries – the Diaoyu/Senkaku Islands dispute – we also examine whether public support for government repression of actions by citizens differs between China and Japan. See full pre-analysis plan for more detail.

q16.value: One may expect nationalist issues such as the Diaoyu/Senkaku Islands dispute to face particularly high costs of repression due the visible and nationally charged nature of the dispute. This suggests that we may find larger treatment effect estimates for our repression treatment in the charged Diaoyu/Senkaku scenario, but smaller effects for our non-nationalist, labor dispute scenario. Treatment effects may also be larger in Japan due to the country’s democratic political system, which should be less receptive to the use of repression. But it is also possible that the government increases its support due to the repression under some conditions (see Heterogenous Treatment Effects section), and larger treatment effects can be observed in China than in Japan. Therefore, depending on the direction of differential treatment effects (if they exist), our experiment may reveal: (1) costless repression for both a democracy and an autocracy (or even “popular” repression), (2) repression that is costly only in a democracy, (3) costly repression only in an autocracy, or (4) costly repression in both an autocracy and democracy. If repression of protests in China increases support for the ruling Chinese Communist Party (CCP) or has a null effect, this would run against the predominant theoretical arguments that repression is costly in authoritarian regimes. In Japan, if even some subgroups support repression (e.g. supporters of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party), this would add nuance to current theories of the high costs of repression in democracies. Our experiment is also unique in the sense that we consider both nationalist and non- nationalist scenarios. For both scenarios, we consider all the possible outcomes described above: (1) costless repression for both a democracy and an autocracy (or even “popular” repression), (2) repression that is costly only in a democracy, (3) costly repression only in an autocracy, or (4) costly repression in both an autocracy and democracy. Although we may observe similar repression costs for both scenarios, it is possible that some citizens in both or either countries may find it easier to support or oppose the government’s repression in either scenario. This leads to twelve possible combinations in terms of treatment effects, summarized in Table 1. See full pre-analysis plan for more detail.

q17.value: Our research design takes the form of a survey experiment administered in the form of a vignette to 3000 respondents in both China and Japan (6,000 respondents total). The experiment considers whether there are indeed costs to each type of repression, whether the costs of repression differ by type (nationalist and economic), whether the costs of repression differ by regime of interest (China and Japan), and whether the costs of repression differ amongst different groups of respondents. We test for costs of repression by calculating difference-in-means in our treatment group minus our control group. Differential costs of repression by type are estimated by comparing the magnitude of our treatment effect estimates in each of our treatment arms – nationalist and economic. Differential costs of repression by regime are estimated by comparing the magnitude of our treatment effects estimates in each of our surveys – China and Japan. Finally, we look for the existence of heterogenous treatment effects across a battery of pre- treatment covariates by regressing our outcome variable on treatments conditional upon the data representing the covariate of interest, as well as using Bayesian Additive Regression Trees (BART). See full pre-analysis plan for more detail.

q27.value: Nikkei Research (Japan) and Survey Sampling International (Mainland China)

attributes.title: Violence and Support for Internally Displaced Persons - Evidence from Syria

q1.value: Violence and Support for Internally Displaced Persons - Evidence from Syria

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: According to the UNHCR, there are currently more refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) than at any time since the end of World War II. In response, humanitarian agencies and host-country governments have increasingly called on ordinary citizens to welcome refugees into their homes and communities through resettlement and local integration programs (UNHCR 2013). However, little is known about what motivates members of the host population to incur the costs and risks of hosting refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs). Research from conflict-affected countries is especially scarce due to the challenges associated with collecting data in these settings, yet it is precisely these countries where the need for research is most pressing, as the overwhelming majority of those forcibly displaced by violence flee within their countries or to neighboring countries that have themselves been affected by conflict in the recent past. To address this gap, we collaborated with an international humanitarian organization to conduct a survey in four governorates of Syrian. In addition to information on economic activity, medical needs, and food security, the survey collected information on past experiences with displacement and their willingness to offer assistance to IDPs from other parts of Syria. The latter topic -– willingness to offer assistance to IDPs –- was elicited through a conjoint experiment in which respondents were presented vignettes of hypothetical IDP families, with each family varying along several dimensions (e.g. region of origin, gender of household head, level of need, and occupation). This pre-analysis plan outlines how we will use these data to assess the influence of economic, humanitarian, and identity-based concerns on individuals' willingness to offer assistance to refugees. In addition, we will assess how past experiences with violence and displacement influence the relative importance of economic, humanitarian, and identity-based factors, as well as overall willingness to host. This pre-analysis plan is being written after data was collected but before the researchers have been given access to the data.

q16.value: We expect that respondents will be concerned about the well-being of refugees, and will thus be more willing to accept IDPs who are sick or headed by a single-mother, all else equal. We also expect respondents to hold ingroup preferences, and thus to prefer coethnic and coreligious refugees, all else equal. We do not have a clear hypothesis regarding the impact of prewar professional occupation | on the one hand, a professional working background may be interpreted as a signal of greater wealth and therefore greater ability to remunerate, or it may be seen as a sign of greater education or other desirable attributes, leading to a positive impact on the likelihood of being hosted; on the other hand, respondents may infer that those who come from a professional working background are better positioned to access assistance elsewhere, and may thus prefer farmers on account of their greater need. In terms of heterogeneous treatment effects, we expect that those who've previously experienced violence or displacement to place greater emphasis on the well-being of IDPs and less emphasis on their ethnic or religious identity, relative to those who with more limited exposure to violence and displacement. Thus, we expect having a sick child or a single mother as the household head to have a larger positive effect among those who've previously experienced violence or displacement, as compared to those who have not. By the same logic, we expect coethnicity and coreligiousity to have a smaller positive effect among those who've previously experience violence or displacement, as compared to those who have not. We will also assess the relationship between past experience with violence and displacement and actual hosting behavior. Our hypothesis is that those with relatively higher levels of past experience with violence and displacement will be more likely to host IDPs, and that conditional hosting, they will host them for longer.

q17.value: We test these hypotheses using data collected in collaboration with a humanitarian NGO as part of a needs assessment for communities adversely affected by the Syrian conflict. In total, the survey was administered to 2310 respondents. In addition to collecting information on health and welfare, the survey included a conjoint experiment in which respondents were asked to evaluate IDP families whose attributes randomly varied along five dimensions: ethnicity, religion, child health, profession, and the status of the household head. We use the data from this experiment to test our hypotheses regarding which types of families respondents will be most likely to be willing to host. The survey also collects information on past experiences with displacement and violence, and for those currently (re)settled, whether they are currently hosting refugees. We use these data to test our hypotheses regarding past experience with violence and displacement and actual hosting behavior. Both of these analyses are outlined in greater detail in accompanying PAP.

In response, humanitarian agencies and host-country governments have increasingly called on ordinary citizens to welcome refugees into their homes and communities through resettlement and local integration programs (UNHCR 2013). However, little is known about what motivates members of the host population to incur the costs and risks of hosting refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs). Research from conflict-affected countries is especially scarce due to the challenges associated with collecting data in these settings, yet it is precisely these countries where the need for research is most pressing, as the overwhelming majority of those forcibly displaced by violence flee within their countries or to neighboring countries that have themselves been affected by conflict in the recent past. To address this gap, we collaborated with an international humanitarian organization to conduct a survey in four governorates of Syrian. In addition to information on economic activity, medical needs, and food security, the survey collected information on past experiences with displacement and their willingness to offer assistance to IDPs from other parts of Syria. The latter topic -– willingness to offer assistance to IDPs –- was elicited through a conjoint experiment in which respondents were presented vignettes of hypothetical IDP families, with each family varying along several dimensions (e.g. region of origin, gender of household head, level of need, and occupation). This pre-analysis plan outlines how we will use these data to assess the influence of economic, humanitarian, and identity-based concerns on individuals' willingness to offer assistance to refugees. In addition, we will assess how past experiences with violence and displacement influence the relative importance of economic, humanitarian, and identity-based factors, as well as overall willingness to host. This pre-analysis plan is being written after data was collected but before the researchers have been given access to the data.
registration_responses.q16: We expect that respondents will be concerned about the well-being of refugees, and will thus be more willing to accept IDPs who are sick or headed by a single-mother, all else equal. We also expect respondents to hold ingroup preferences, and thus to prefer coethnic and coreligious refugees, all else equal. We do not have a clear hypothesis regarding the impact of prewar professional occupation | on the one hand, a professional working background may be interpreted as a signal of greater wealth and therefore greater ability to remunerate, or it may be seen as a sign of greater education or other desirable attributes, leading to a positive impact on the likelihood of being hosted; on the other hand, respondents may infer that those who come from a professional working background are better positioned to access assistance elsewhere, and may thus prefer farmers on account of their greater need. In terms of heterogeneous treatment effects, we expect that those who've previously experienced violence or displacement to place greater emphasis on the well-being of IDPs and less emphasis on their ethnic or religious identity, relative to those who with more limited exposure to violence and displacement. Thus, we expect having a sick child or a single mother as the household head to have a larger positive effect among those who've previously experienced violence or displacement, as compared to those who have not. By the same logic, we expect coethnicity and coreligiousity to have a smaller positive effect among those who've previously experience violence or displacement, as compared to those who have not. We will also assess the relationship between past experience with violence and displacement and actual hosting behavior. Our hypothesis is that those with relatively higher levels of past experience with violence and displacement will be more likely to host IDPs, and that conditional hosting, they will host them for longer.
registration_responses.q17: We test these hypotheses using data collected in collaboration with a humanitarian NGO as part of a needs assessment for communities adversely affected by the Syrian conflict. In total, the survey was administered to 2310 respondents. In addition to collecting information on health and welfare, the survey included a conjoint experiment in which respondents were asked to evaluate IDP families whose attributes randomly varied along five dimensions: ethnicity, religion, child health, profession, and the status of the household head. We use the data from this experiment to test our hypotheses regarding which types of families respondents will be most likely to be willing to host. The survey also collects information on past experiences with displacement and violence, and for those currently (re)settled, whether they are currently hosting refugees. We use these data to test our hypotheses regarding past experience with violence and displacement and actual hosting behavior. Both of these analyses are outlined in greater detail in accompanying PAP.
